publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday January 23, 2019 at 05:04

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Harrison Smith Papers contain writings, correspondence, printed material, and photographs that document the life and work of editor and publisher Harrison Smith, particularly his research on American author Sinclair Lewis, and his editorial work for the Saturday Review of Literature. Series I, Research Files on Sinclair Lewis, includes extensive biographical notes, presumably intended as the source material for a book-length biography of Lewis. Series II, Other Papers, consists chiefly of writings, interviews, and speeches that relate to the position of women in early- and mid-twentieth century society.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization, in 2013. Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 363.

bioghist.head: Harrison Smith (1888-1971)
bioghist.p: Harrison Smith (Yale College 1911) was born Oliver Harrison Smith in Hartford, Connecticut on August 4, 1888. He received a bachelor's degree from Yale College in 1911, and a Master's degree in 1914. Smith's lifelong career in publishing began as an editorial assistant and textbook salesman, then eventually as an editor for Harcourt, Brace and Company (1918 to 1928). In 1929 he founded the firm Jonathan Cape & Harrison Smith, and went on to become a partner at Random House and an editor at Doubleday Doran & Company. From 1938 until 1966 he was president and associate editor of the Saturday Review of Literature . Smith wrote extensively on topics in American Literature, and on issues relating to working women and feminism after the Second World War. In 1952 he edited From Main Street to Stockholm , a volume of Sinclair Lewis correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Harrison Smith Papers contain writings, correspondence, printed material, and photographs that document the life and work of editor and publisher Harrison Smith, particularly his research on American author Sinclair Lewis, and his editorial work for the Saturday Review of Literature . Series I, Research Files on Sinclair Lewis, includes extensive biographical notes, presumably intended as the source material for a book-length biography of Lewis. Series II, Other Papers, consists chiefly of writings, interviews, and speeches that relate to the position of women in early- and mid-twentieth century society.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two series: I. Research Files on Sinclair Lewis, 1904-1962. II. Other Papers, 1935-1975.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into eight subseries: Writings of Sinclair Lewis; Writings about Sinclair Lewis; Source Material; Sinclair Lewis Letters; Correspondence about Sinclair Lewis; Printed Matter by Sinclair Lewis; Printed Matter about Sinclair Lewis; Photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copies, proofs, and typescripts of writings by Sinclair Lewis, accompanied by editors' notes and related material.

did.unittitle: Fools, Liars, and Mr. De Veto, proofs
Page of notes in Lewis's handwriting

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typescript drafts and copies of drafts of essays, interviews, and articles about Sinclair Lewis. Many of the typescripts are transcribed from printed versions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Copies of letters from Sinclair Lewis to named correspondents, accompanied by Harrison Smith notes and correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence between Harrison Smith and named correspondents, copies of third-party correspondence relating to Sinclair Lewis, and related notes and clippings.

scopecontent.p: Also includes letter from Mrs. F. A. Summers

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into seven subseries: Writings of Harrison Smith; Writings of Others; Speeches and Interviews of Harrison Smith; Correspondence; Financial Papers and Agreements; Printed Matter; Photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Writings of Harrison Smith consist of typescript drafts, corrected. Some files include related material such as clippings, notes, and correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Writings of others consist chiefly of typescript drafts, some corrected, of short works of journalism and literary criticism.

Speeches and Interviews of Harrison Smith

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consist of typescript drafts of speeches by, and interviews with, Harrison Smith, addressing social and literary topics. Several speeches address the position of women in society.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into files by topic, with General Correspondence filed at the end.
